title: Trump impondrá aranceles adicionales de 25% a Japón y Corea del Sur
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, envió este lunes las primeras cartas anunciando nuevos aranceles a los países con los que no avanza en acuerdos comerciales, y aseguró que Japón y Corea ...
resumen:
Donald Trump impondrá aranceles adicionales de 25% a Japón y Corea del Sur.
Trump firmará este lunes un decreto para oficializar esa decisión, indicó la portavoz de la Casa Blanca, Karoline Leavitt.
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, envió este lunes las primeras cartas anunciando nuevos aranceles a los países con los que no avanza en acuerdos comerciales, y aseguró que Japón y Corea del Sur tendrán tasas adicionales de 25%.
En dos misivas prácticamente idénticas, Trump señaló que los nuevos aranceles a Japón y Corea del Sur entrarán en vigor el 1 de agosto puesto que las relaciones comerciales se hallan "desafortunadamente lejos de ser recíprocas".
En el caso de Corea del Sur, se trata de la misma tasa que había anunciado Trump en abril, mientras que para Japón se eleva ligeramente desde el 24% previsto inicialmente por el mandatario republicano.
Trump había adelantado que enviaría este lunes un primer lote de cartas a 15 socios comerciales, en las que recordará la necesidad de sellar un pacto para evitar esos gravámenes.
El primer ministro de Japón, Shigeru Ishib, había dicho el domingo que no "cedería fácilmente" en las conversaciones comerciales con Washington.
Inicialmente estaba previsto que los nuevos aranceles entraran en vigor el 9 de julio, pero el plazo ha sido extendido ahora hasta el 1 de agosto.
Trump impuso aranceles de 10% a casi todos sus socios comerciales en abril, y amenazó con tasas incluso más altas a algunas economías, como la Unión Europea.
El secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent, dijo el lunes en una entrevista con CNBC que se esperan varios anuncios en las próximas 48 horas.
El secretario del Tesoro indicó que en las cartas el presidente recordará a los países la tasa del arancel que tendrán que pagar sus productos a menos que quieran "volver e intentar negociar".
Hasta ahora, Trump solo ha alcanzado acuerdos comerciales con Reino Unido y Vietnam.
Bessent prevé reunirse con su homólogo chino en las próximas dos semanas.
Estados Unidos y China acordaron reducir hasta mediados de agosto las tasas de aranceles mutuos que llegaron a alcanzar los tres dígitos.
El mandatario estadounidense amenazó con un arancel suplementario del 10% a los países que se alineen con los BRICS.
Trump calificó de "antiestadounidense" al bloque fundado por Brasil, Rusia, India, China y Sudáfrica, que incluye a once países.
Sus declaraciones fueron rechazadas de inmediato por el presidente brasileño Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

title: Media’s Trump Tariff Inflation Fear Mongering Turns Out To Be Total Dud
content: Corporate media repeatedly predicted that President Donald Trump’s tariffs would lead to price hikes —only for those forecasts to be ...
resumen: Corporate media repeatedly predicted that President Donald Trump’s tariffs would lead to price hikes —only for those forecasts to be repeatedly proven wrong. Trump imposed steep reciprocal tariffs on numerous countries on April 2 before announcing a 90-day pause that lowered most of them to a 10% baseline. Despite the 10% duties and persistent media warnings, inflation has not surged. ABC News on March 26 cited “experts” to report that fresh tariffs “would ratchet up the global trade war, raising prices for an array of consumer goods and risking an economic slowdown.” A May 13 CNBC piece acknowledged that inflation had “eased” in April despite the tariffs, it warned prices could rise as the duties took hold. Inflation also rose less than expected in May, falling to a four-year low. The Guardian ran an April 22 opinion piece asserting that tariffs would inevitably increase prices. NewsNation host Chris Cuomo claimed on “The Chris Cuomo Project” in February that tariffs were bound to influence inflation. CNN acknowledged that tariff inflation warnings have yet to prove accurate. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent argued on “Pod Force One” June 18 that those predicting doom due to Trump’s duties have “tariff derangement syndrome.” The consumer price index (CPI) — a broad measure of the prices of everyday goods — only rose by a seasonally adjusted 0.1% in May, according to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) published on June 11. The Producer Price Index rose by the same rate in May, according to the BLS. The U.S. economy added 147,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in June, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) data published on Thursday. Economists’ projections estimated that the U.S. economy added 106,000 jobs in June.

title: Trump uses tariffs to penalise Russia
content: Donald Trump is using tariffs to punish Russia as Vladimir Putin’s military bombards Ukraine with missiles. The US President ramped up his global trade war on Monday as he said countries seeking ...
resumen:
Donald Trump is using tariffs to punish Russia as Vladimir Putin’s military bombards Ukraine with missiles.

Trump said countries seeking closer ties with the “anti-American” group of Brics nations, which includes Russia, would face extra tariffs of 10pc.

Trump unleashed a fresh wave of levies on 14 countries including Kazakhstan.

The 11-nation Brics alliance took aim at US trade policy during a summit in Brazil this weekend, saying Mr Trump’s tariffs “distort trade and are inconsistent with WTO rules”.

The original Brics alliance of Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa was extended last year to include Egypt, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Iran, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.

Trump said: “Any country aligning themselves with the Anti-American policies of Brics, will be charged an additional 10pc tariff. There will be no exceptions to this policy.”

Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, accused the Brics nations of “seeking to undermine the interests of the United States”.

Trump suggested in April that a truce between the two sides was “pretty close” but he has become increasingly frustrated with Putin’s regime.

Russia carried out its largest drone and missile barrage on Ukraine since it launched its invasion in February 2022, sending 530 drones and around a dozen missiles on Kyiv in an attack that killed at least two people.

Russia was not targeted in the President’s “Liberation Day” tariffs on April 2 but is subject to US sanctions.

Trump’s warning sparked criticism from South African president Cyril Ramaphosa.

Trump sent letters to 14 countries announcing that all of their goods imports to the US would be subject to new higher tariff rates as of August 1.

South African and Bosnian imports will be hit with a 30pc levy, while Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Tunisia and Kazakhstan will all be subject to 25pc tariffs. Goods from Laos and Myanmar will each be hit with charges of 40pc.

He also imposed tariffs between 32pc and 36pc on Serbia, Indonesia, Bangladesh, Thailand and Cambodia.

These new rates are broadly in line with the “reciprocal” charges Mr Trump imposed on each of these nations on April 2, which he then suspended the following week, replacing them with a blanket 10pc levy.

US stocks slumped after Trump began announcing the tariff rates before markets closed on Monday night.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average and the Nasdaq sank 0.9pc on the day, while S&P 500 closed down 0.8pc.

President Trump and his team have been able to complete only a limited trade deal with Britain and an agreement with Vietnam.

Ms Leavitt told reporters that Mr Trump would sign an executive order extending the July 9 deadline for a reprieve on his reciprocal tariffs to August 1 for all of America’s trading partners.

The tariffs will be separate from the levies Mr Trump has already imposed on industries including steel and cars.

The letters warned that goods transhipped through other countries to evade the charges would also be subject to the higher tariffs.

title: Trump’s trade war threats reshape global markets
content: Trump's Renewed Tariff Arsenal The president's latest offensive targets Japan and South Korea with potential 25% tariffs, escalating to ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump has rekindled his combative trade approach in the opening months of his second administration, deploying tariff threats as diplomatic weapons against key U.S. allies and trading partners.

The president’s latest offensive targets Japan and South Korea with potential 25% tariffs, escalating to even higher penalties for goods that undergo transshipment.

These announcements, delivered through social media correspondence, represent a dramatic return to the unpredictable trade policies that characterized Trump’s earlier tenure.

The threats gained momentum following Trump’s Liberation Day address on April 2, where he signaled his intention to impose substantial trade barriers on multiple nations.

Financial markets responded predictably, with stock indices tumbling as investors grappled with the implications of renewed trade hostilities.

Countries including Laos, Myanmar, South Africa, Malaysia and Kazakhstan now face potential tariffs ranging from 25% to 40%.

These measures would be implemented under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, though their constitutional validity remains under judicial scrutiny.

The S&P 500 index shed 1% in immediate response to these announcements, underscoring the market’s sensitivity to trade policy shifts.

Originally scheduled for July 9, the negotiation deadline has been extended to August 1 following a White House executive order.

Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt confirmed the extension, acknowledging the administration’s return to the erratic trade policies that once defined Trump’s presidential approach.

Despite the aggressive rhetoric, Trump‘s administration has announced few concrete trade arrangements.

Preliminary agreements with the United Kingdom and China have been mentioned, along with a brief reference to a Vietnamese pact, though details remain largely undisclosed.

The president has also threatened an additional 10% tariff on nations aligning with the BRICS economic bloc, which encompasses Brazil, Russia, China and India.

Capital Economics analysts suggest the current tariff uncertainty may not devastate the U.S. economy as severely as previous trade wars.

The Federal Reserve faces renewed challenges as tariff-driven inflation concerns complicate monetary policy decisions.

Elevated interest rates, maintained partly due to import tax pressures, have increased borrowing costs for consumers and businesses nationwide.

Estados Unidos comenzará a notificar a los países las tarifas que regirán a partir del 1 de agosto.
El sector exportador ecuatoriano espera que Estados Unidos elimine el arancel del 10 % que desde abril pasado se aplica a los productos nacionales que ingresan a ese mercado.
El Gobierno ecuatoriano emprendió un proceso de negociación con la Administración estadounidense, en el que se abordaron los 16 obstáculos comerciales que la Oficina de Comercio de EE. UU. identificó en el caso ecuatoriano.

Ecuador es uno de los países a la espera de esa resolución.
La imposición del arancel en abril por parte de la Administración de Donald Trump encendió las alarmas del sector exportador nacional, que de inmediato activó gestiones a través del Ministerio de Producción, Comercio Exterior, Inversiones y Pesca.
Durante 2024, Ecuador exportó USD 5 043 millones a Estados Unidos e importó bienes por 2 736 millones, dejando una balanza comercial positiva de USD 2 307 millones.
El sector bananero enfrenta un sobrecosto anual estimado en 70 millones de dólares debido al arancel.
Richard Salazar, director ejecutivo de la Asociación de Comercialización y Exportación de Banano (Acorbanec), aseguró que "El país está entre los primeros 19 que llegarán a un acuerdo con Estados Unidos".
La primera señal fue la reducción de aranceles para vehículos estadounidenses, que pasaron del 35-40 % al 10 %.
En la mesa de diálogo se han tratado temas sensibles como los aranceles mixtos aplicados a productos estadounidenses, los cupos de importación, los subsidios al diésel, las regulaciones de etiquetado, la contratación pública, las barreras técnicas y sanitarias, e incluso el impuesto a la salida de divisas.
La meta del Gobierno Nacional y del sector exportador es lograr un acuerdo comercial duradero con Estados Unidos.

title: US dollar has worst first half in more than 50 years amid Trump tariffs
content: WASHINGTON: The US dollar has had its worst first half-year in more than 50 years, as the financial markets over ...
resumen: The US dollar has had its worst first half-year in more than 50 years. The dollar has fallen by 10.8% against a basket of currencies since the start of 2025, its worst performance over the first six months of any year since 1973, and the worst half-year since the second half of 1991. This sell-off has pulled the dollar index down to its lowest level since March 2022 and lifted the pound to a three-year high of $1.37, up from $1.25 at the start of the year. Investors have been selling the US currency due to concerns that Trump’s economic policies threaten the safe-haven role of US dollar-denominated assets. Analysts at Unicredit said: “The US dollar is the most notable loser so far this year as it has lost 10% against other currencies, with investor concerns regarding Trump’s policies having weighed on the greenback. On the other hand, the euro has risen by 5%.” David Morrison, a senior market analyst at the financial services company Trade Nation, said: “Trump’s tariffs, the fact that many investors view his administration as somewhat chaotic, along with concerns over US national debt have seen the dollar fall out of favour.” Rising expectations of US interest rate cuts have also hurt the dollar. The S&P 500 has only gained 5% during 2025 so far, slower than the pan-European Stoxx 600 (+7%), the UK’s FTSE 100 (up 7.2%), or Germany’s Dax (up 20%). The UK has been one of the best-performing regions globally for investors in the first half of 2025.

content: NEW YORK >> When Plufl co-founders Yuki Kinoshita and Noah Silverman pitched their “dog beds for humans” prototype to Shark Tank in 2022, they envisioned making the plush, snuggly, memory foam beds in ...
resumen:
In 2022, Plufl co-founders Yuki Kinoshita and Noah Silverman pitched their “dog beds for humans” prototype to Shark Tank, envisioning making the beds in China and selling them at retail in the U.S. for $299. Mark Cuban and Lori Greiner invested $200,000 jointly for 20% of the company. In 2023, the company made over $1 million in sales, selling beds on Amazon and their own website. After U.S. President Donald Trump slapped a 145% tariff on items imported from China in April, Kinoshita and Silverman investigated making a U.S. made version of their human dog beds. The retail price might go higher, but they thought a “made-in-the-USA” label might be an attractive selling point. Silverman and Kinoshita had previously toured a factory in Las Vegas that could make the memory foam beds for $150 per unit compared to the $100 overall cost to make the beds in China. The $150 manufacturing cost didn’t include the faux fur lining for the cover, which would still need to be imported from China—adding another $100 per unit. They pitched a sub-$500 made-in-the-USA version to Costco, which it turned down. On June 11, when Trump announced a deal to lower tariffs on Chinese goods to 55%, Kinoshita and Silverman decided to stay the course manufacturing their human dog beds in China and maintain the $299 retail price.

Aisha Chottani, CEO-founder of Moment, makes her healthy, stress-reducing carbonated beverages in Wisconsin, but her packager, CanWorks imports pre-formed aluminum from China, and is thus subject to aluminum tariffs which raised the price of cans from by 20%. When Chottani tried to pass on the 4 cents in additional costs to Albertsons, which carries her $3.99 “Strawberry Rose” beverage at about 30 locations in Texas and New Mexico, her answer was swift. In February, she launched Moment beverages in Sprout Farmers Markets across the U.S., but was forced to do so with higher-priced cans. For now, Chottani is keeping her wholesale price the same even as her costs have gone up.

Bugaboo, the Netherlands-based maker of expensive baby gear, owns its own factory in China. The company’s popular “Fox 5” stroller, which retails for about $1,500 in the U.S., is made at its factory in Xiamen, China. When Trump’s tariffs hit, Bugaboo started to reevaluate that strategy. The company had begun studying moving production to other countries in Asia to have more regional production flexibility as well as the U.S., but any move would be years away. Bugaboo decided to pass some of those costs onto customers, raising prices $50 to $300 on several products including high chairs, play pens, and a new version the Fox 5 stroller on May 20.

Simplified, maker of high-end notebooks, cards and stationery, can make a day planner complete with a hard cover, gold corners, foil and color printing for about $12 in Shenzhen, China. Producing the same planner in the U.S. would cost $38. Ley said she keeps her manufacturing costs at 25% of the $64 retail price of the planners. She said she can’t pass on the cost of tariffs, because then her planners would cost $100. Ley has filed a lawsuit against Trump alleging that his use of emergency powers to enact tariffs was illegal.

title: El banco de los BRICS descarta una "desdolarización" a pesar de las dudas por Trump
content: Río de Janeiro, 5 jul (EFE).- La presidenta del banco de fomento de los BRICS, Dilma Rousseff, afirmó que no observa "ninguna señal de desdolarización" en el mundo, a pesar de las dudas que ha generad ...
resumen:
La presidenta del banco de fomento de los BRICS, Dilma Rousseff, afirmó que no observa "ninguna señal de desdolarización" en el mundo, a pesar de las dudas que ha generado la guerra arancelaria del gobernante estadounidense, Donald Trump.

Rousseff explicó que sí percibe que "muchos países están usando sus propias monedas para comerciar", es decir, "mucha diversificación" más allá del dólar como moneda hegemónica.

Rousseff analizó que "nadie está queriendo asumir el lugar de Estados Unidos" porque ello implica algunos riesgos.

Rousseff explicó que el dólar, como moneda hegemónica, implica que Estados Unidos consigue financiarse a costos bajos, pero también genera déficit en la cuenta corriente, lo que ha llevado a la desindustrialización del país, en su opinión.

Rousseff ve "extremadamente complicado" que se esté produciendo una "desdolarización" como fenómeno generalizado.

Rousseff citó que el pasado 2 de abril, en el llamado 'Día de la Liberación', cuando Trump impuso aranceles universales y castigó severamente a algunos de sus principales socios, ocurrió algo "extraño".

Rousseff apuntó que con el episodio de los aranceles ocurrió lo contrario de 2008 (durante la crisis financiera) y que por eso, han comenzado a decir que la condición del dólar como puerto seguro estaba siendo cuestionada por el mercado.

Rousseff apostó por "esperar y ver", pero insistió en que no observa "claramente, ninguna señal de desdolarización" y que quien pone en marcha ese tipo de movimientos es "el mercado financiero internacional".

Rousseff afirmó que el banco de los BRICS no tiene condiciones para interferir en el mercado y que su área es principalmente la inversión, no especulación.

Uno de los ejes de la cumbre de líderes de los BRICS en Río de Janeiro, que se celebrará este domingo y lunes, será precisamente la cooperación comercial en un contexto de alta inestabilidad desde la guerra de aranceles de Trump.

Se espera que los líderes del foro liderado por China, Rusia, India, Brasil y Sudáfrica hagan una férrea defensa del multilateralismo y condenen el proteccionismo.

Trump ha amenazado con imponer aranceles adicionales del 100 %, si los emergentes toman medidas que pongan en tela de juicio la hegemonía del dólar en el comercio internacional.

title: Francia espera acuerdo UE-UU sobre los aranceles este fin de semana
content: EL NUEVO DIARIO, PARÍS.- El ministro francés de Economía, Éric Lombard, dijo este sábado que espera que la Unión Europea y Estados Unidos alcancen un acuerdo sobre aranceles este fin de semana.
resumen: El ministro francés de Economía, Éric Lombard, dijo este sábado que espera que la Unión Europea y Estados Unidos alcancen un acuerdo sobre aranceles este fin de semana. Lombard confió en que se llegue a un acuerdo este fin de semana durante su intervención en los Encuentros Económicos de Aix-en-Provence. Si no hay un acuerdo entre Bruselas y Washington, «Europa probablemente tendrá que mostrar más firmeza en la respuesta para restablecer el equilibrio» en la relación con Estados Unidos. El responsable económico francés insistió en que «es absolutamente necesario cambiar las reglas del juego» en términos generales de política comercial, y refiriéndose especialmente a China. China «va a matar a nuestra industria» con su política de superar el 50 % de la capacidad mundial de producción en cada sector industrial. La UE ya ha comenzado a defenderse contra barreras comerciales en los sectores del acero y del automóvil frente a las exportaciones chinas. Si además nos enfrentamos a los estadounidenses por los aranceles anunciados por el presidente Donald Trump, «tendremos dificultades de verdad. El comisario europeo de Comercio, Maros Sefcovic, informó este viernes a los países de la UE sobre el estado de las negociaciones para evitar una escalada de aranceles con Estados Unidos. La UE y EE. UU. siguen en conversaciones para alcanzar un acuerdo antes del 9 de julio, fecha en la que Washington tiene previsto incrementar los gravámenes a productos comunitarios en caso de no alcanzarse un pacto arancelario.

title: EU ready for trade war if Trump slaps 17% tariffs on its food and farm produce
content: The EU and the US are racing toward a trade deal before Wednesday’s deadline. If no agreement is reached, they are both ready for a trade war ...
resumen: Donald Trump threatens the EU with tariffs, the EU prefers negotiations, but is ready for a trade war. Donald Trump has threatened the EU with a 17% tariff on its food and farm exports. The threat landed in Brussels after EU Trade Commissioner Maroš Šefčovič received the warning in person during talks in Washington this week. Among those at the table: Trump’s economic lieutenants, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, Trade Representative Jamieson Greer, and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick. Trump intends to send formal letters to a dozen countries warning of permanent tariffs reaching up to 70% unless they reach a deal by his self-imposed July 9 deadline. The EU is prepared for a potential trade war with retaliatory tariffs on everything from Bourbon to Boeing 747s if Trump walks away before Wednesday. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen confirmed that the EU was seeking a high-level framework deal. The EU is also seeking immediate relief from tariffs in key sectors as part of the framework, including the auto industry, which has to deal with a 27.5 per cent tariff, up from 2.5 per cent before Trump started his trade aggression. The 90-day pause on Trump’s “liberation tariffs” ends on Wednesday for more than 60 countries in addition to the EU, which was more recently threatened with a 50 per cent tariff. The EU won’t blink if the U.S. goes through with its threat. EU trade spokesperson Olof Gill said on Friday evening that the EU’s priority continued to “favour a negotiated solution”. Negotiations would continue “on substance over the weekend”. The U.S. and EU are no longer speaking the same trade language. One of the key fractures lies in digital regulation. The U.S. sees those rules—particularly when applied to Silicon Valley giants—as targeted trade restrictions. Another point of contention is VAT. Trump has long framed Europe’s value-added tax system as a hidden tariff on American goods. The talks are hindered by a total lack of trust.

title: Doce países recibirán el lunes 7 de julio de 2025 cartas de Donald Trump con nuevos aranceles ¿Ecuador estará en esa lista?
content: Este lunes 1 de julio de 2025, EE. UU. enviará las primeras cartas con nuevos aranceles a doce países. Ecuador, que ha estado en plena negociación para revertir un arancel del 10% que afecta a product ...
resumen: El lunes 7 de julio de 2025, doce países recibirán cartas de Donald Trump con nuevos aranceles. El 1 de julio de 2025, EE. UU. enviará las primeras cartas con nuevos aranceles a doce países. Ecuador, que ha estado en plena negociación para revertir un arancel del 10% que afecta a productos clave como el banano, podría estar en la lista. La tregua arancelaria de Donald Trump vence el 9 de julio de 2025. El presidente de EE.UU, Donald Trump, asegura que mantendrá su política arancelaria. El presidente Donald Trump anunció que el lunes 7 de julio de 2025, se enviarán las primeras cartas con nuevas tasas arancelarias de hasta 70% a una docena de países que no han cerrado acuerdos comerciales con EE. UU.. Las misivas contendrán las tarifas deseadas por su administración y los países tendrán hasta el 9 de julio para aceptarlas o enfrentar las consecuencias. La recolección de estos nuevos impuestos iniciaría el 1 de agosto. Ecuador fue incluido, desde abril de 2025, en un grupo de más de 180 naciones a las que se impuso un “arancel recíproco” del 10% por no contar con un tratado comercial vigente con EE. UU.. El pasado 1 de julio concluyó la tercera y última ronda técnica en Washington. La delegación ecuatoriana, liderada por el ministro Luis Alberto Jaramillo, mantuvo reuniones con representantes de la Oficina del Representante Comercial de EE. UU. (USTR). La respuesta final de EE. UU. podría llegar “hasta el 9 de julio”, justo el mismo día en que expira la tregua arancelaria anunciada por Trump. El Gobierno de Daniel Noboa ha insistido en que Ecuador es considerado un país prioritario por la administración estadounidense, al haber sido uno de los 21 invitados a una negociación directa para discutir la aplicación del arancel del 10%. Chile y Costa Rica también integran esta lista. El objetivo inmediato es revertir ese impuesto que afecta especialmente al sector agrícola, en productos clave como el banano, cuya tarifa era del 0% antes de abril. El país también aspira a avanzar hacia un tratado comercial amplio que sustituya las actuales preferencias arancelarias, aún vigentes bajo condiciones unilaterales. Este acuerdo requeriría la aprobación del Congreso estadounidense y el cumplimiento de 16 condiciones: 11 acciones ejecutivas, cuatro reformas legales y una reforma constitucional. En caso de que Ecuador reciba la carta y no acepta los términos propuestos, podría enfrentarse a tasas de hasta el 60% o 70% en productos clave. Trump ha dicho: “Me gustaría simplemente enviar cartas a todos. ¡Felicidades! Vas a pagar el 25%”. Desde el Gobierno de Noboa se ha asegurado que existe moderado optimismo de que se podrá revertir el arancel recíproco del 10% y abrir la puerta a un acuerdo comercial con Estados Unidos. La respuesta definitiva, si no llega este lunes 7 de julio, se conocerá indefectiblemente hasta el miércoles 9 de julio de 2025.

title: Paraguay y Argentina buscan resolver problema de trasbordo de combustible en la hidrovía
content: Asunción, 5 jul (EFE).-La Cancillería de Paraguay informó este sábado que trabaja con autoridades de Argentina para "encontrar una solución" a un problema relacionado con el transbordo de combustible ...
resumen:
La Cancillería de Paraguay informó que trabaja con autoridades de Argentina para «encontrar una solución» a un problema relacionado con el transbordo de combustible en el km 171 de la Hidrovía Paraguay-Paraná, que según organizaciones paraguayas fue suspendido por una agencia aduanera del vecino país.

Los ministros paraguayos de Relaciones Exteriores, Rubén Ramírez; de Industria y Comercio, Javier Giménez; y de Economía y Finanzas, Carlos Fernández, dialogaron sobre el asunto con el ministro de Economía argentino, Luis Caputo, y la secretaria de Energía, María Tettamanti, durante la cumbre del Mercosur, celebrada esta semana en Buenos Aires.

Las autoridades «coincidieron en la necesidad de encontrar una solución al tema».

El presidente de Paraguay, Santiago Peña, conversó con su homólogo argentino, Javier Milei, «y le reiteró la importancia de encontrar una salida consensuada y sostenible para garantizar la libre navegación y el normal abastecimiento de combustibles a través de la Hidrovía».

La Hidrovía Paraguay-Paraná es el corredor natural que conecta al país suramericano con el Atlántico y por donde se transporta cerca del 80 % de su comercio exterior.

La Cámara Nacional de Comercio y Servicios de Paraguay (Cncsp) acusó a la Agencia de Recaudación y Control Aduanero Argentina (Arca) de adoptar «una medida unilateral» que generó la «suspensión de las operaciones de transbordo» en el kilómetro 171 del río Paraná Guazú.

La medida «pone en riesgo la provisión de combustible para Paraguay, al tratarse de un punto clave utilizado de manera continua a lo largo de varias décadas para el transbordo de este tipo de productos».

El Centro de Armadores Fluviales y Marítimos (Cafym) de Paraguay defendió que la Arca adoptó la medida «sin consulta previa ni evaluación de impacto», lo que «amenaza con generar un desabastecimiento estructural» de combustible en Paraguay.

El traslado de las operaciones a otras terminales de la hidrovía, como el brazo del río Paraná las Palmas, implicaría «un aumento de más de 8 días en los tiempo de reposición de combustibles» y una subida «de hasta 70 %» en el costo de la logística fluvial de abastecimiento.

El Cafym instó a las autoridades competentes a revertir la medida para que se «restablezca la operatividad definitiva» en la zona.

title: Donald Trump dijo que comunicará el lunes los nuevos aranceles a las importaciones que regirán desde agosto
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos notificará por carta a los países con los que no llegó a acuerdos sobre las nuevas tasas para los insumos que ingresen al territorio norteamericano. Qué puede pasar con ...
resumen: Donald Trump anunció que firmó 12 cartas comerciales que serán enviadas el lunes 7 de julio a un grupo de países. El presidente de Estados Unidos comunicará en ellas los nuevos aranceles establecidos para ingresar determinados productos al territorio estadounidense. “Me inclino por enviarles una carta indicando qué arancel van a pagar. El valor oscilará entre el 60% o 70% y el 10% o 20%” según el país y el producto, aseguró Trump en conferencia de prensa. La nueva política tarifaria comenzará a regir el 1 de agosto. “El dinero empezará a entrar en EEUU el 1° de agosto”, puntualizó. El 2 de abril, Trump impuso “aranceles recíprocos” de entre el 10 y 50% a la mayoría de sus los socios comerciales. Una semana después decidió pausar la aplicación de la medida y mantuvo un mínimo del 10% de base hasta el 9 de julio. En mayo, Estados Unidos autorizó una pausa de 90 días para aplicar las nuevas políticas, pero mantuvo un arancel mínimo del 10% hasta el 9 de julio. Este lunes 7 de julio, el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump comunicará a cada país el porcentaje que tendrán que pagar desde agosto sus productos para entrar al territorio norteamericano. Se trata de 12 documentos y resta conocer si la Argentina será uno de los países notificados. Desde abril, Estados Unidos mantiene para la Argentina aranceles del 10% a las importaciones que suman al recargo del 25% que impuso al acero y al aluminio. Semanas después del anuncio de Trump, el secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent visitó Buenos Aires y se reunió con el presidente Javier Milei y su equipo económico liderado por Luis Caputo.

title: Trump anunciará aranceles con cartas, ¿Colombia recibirá el documento?
content: El mandatario confirmó que el 7 de julio enviará al menos 12 cartas a distintos socios comerciales para informar de los aranceles que impondrá a sus mercancías.
resumen:
El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, afirmó que su administración enviará el lunes 7 de julio una docena de cartas a distintos socios comerciales para informar de los aranceles que impondrá a sus mercancías.

El 9 de julio expira el plazo dado por Trump a decenas de economías para negociar un acuerdo que evite la imposición de tarifas aduaneras adicionales que, según afirmó esta misma semana, se situarán entre un 10% y un 70%.

Trump dijo que los países destinarios de estas misivas se anunciarán ese mismo lunes.

El enfoque de las cartas está en los principales aliados comerciales de Estados Unidos, los que más influyen en la economía estadounidense y que también recibieron la mayor presión arancelaria anunciada a principios de abril por Donald Trump.

Los países que tuvieron mayor gravamen arancelario y que tienen mayor relación económica con Estados Unidos fueron China (34%), Vietnam (46%), Unión Europea (20%), Japón (24%), Corea del Sur (25%), India (26%), Camboya (49%), Taiwán (32%), Singapur (10%), Israel (17%), Suiza (31%), Sudáfrica (30%) o Reino Unido (10%).

Estas naciones serían las que recibirían las cartas salvo China, Vietnam, Reino Unido y Camboya, que ya han logrado un nuevo acuerdo comercial con Washington.

Otro país que obtendría la carta es Canadá, con quien Donald Trump suspendió las negociaciones comerciales luego de que ese país impusiera aranceles a servicios digitales estadounidenses.

Hay otros países que mantienen una relación comercial importante con Estados Unidos como Colombia, Panamá, Ucrania, Ecuador, El Salvador, Egipto o Turquía, pero que tienen el nivel arancelario en 10% y, pese a su cercanía con Estados Unidos, no serían los que recibirían carta de repunte arancelario inminente.

A principios de abril, Trump impuso un arancel del 10% a los bienes de casi todos los socios comerciales estadounidenses, y preveía añadir a los pocos días un tramo suplementario para varios de ellos como Taiwán y la Unión Europea.

A pocos días de la fecha límite del 9 de julio, Trump dijo que informará de los nuevos aranceles a los distintos países con el envío de cartas.

title: Experts debate the impact of U.S. tariff policy on the Dominican Republic.
content: President Donald Trump has imposed 10% tariffs on Dominican products imported into the United States. Although this measure could have a direct impact on economic growth and financial stability in the ...
resumen:
Experts debate the impact of U.S. tariff policy on the Dominican Republic.

Since April 5, 2025, President Donald Trump has imposed 10% tariffs on Dominican products imported into the United States.

Local and international experts indicated that these new policies create new challenges for the national economy, especially in promoting the development of free trade zones and creating new actions to address the new tariffs.

The meeting was held at the JW Marriott Hotel under the theme “Impacts and risks of the United States tariff policy on the Dominican Republic’s financial sector Sector” by the Dominican Republic Risk Management Club (CGRRD) and the Deloitte professional services network.

Fabio Salas, Tax and Legal Services Partner, and Daniel González, Senior Manager of Economic Analysis, both at Deloitte, provided insight into the historical context of these new measures, as well as the current outlook for the nation to implement them.

For González, this tariff policy would only be sustainable in the short term.

He stated that it responded more to trade imbalances in those countries that had a trade surplus, and the government reacted somewhat, also driven by its voter base.

He added that these tariff increases typically raise prices for consumers in the country that imposes them, leading to increased inflation, a reduction in purchasing power, and harming those they are intended to benefit.

The event also featured expert panels discussing how Dominican companies can adapt to overcome the challenges of the new tariffs while maintaining competitiveness, as well as the impact of this policy on credit risk.

title: Los países del BRICS se reunirán este domingo en Río de Janeiro en una cumbre marcada por las ausencias de Xi Jinping y Vladimir Putin
content: El bloque debatirá alternativas al dólar en el comercio internacional, abordará la situación en Medio Oriente y Ucrania, y enfrenta obstáculos internos para alcanzar consensos entre sus once miembros, ...
resumen:
La cumbre anual de los BRICS comienza este domingo en Río de Janeiro, reuniendo a representantes de once países emergentes, pero sin la presencia de los líderes de China, Xi Jinping, y de Rusia, Vladimir Putin. El foro, fundado por Brasil, Rusia, India, China y Sudáfrica, se desarrollará bajo presión internacional, especialmente desde Estados Unidos, cuyo presidente Donald Trump mantiene amenazas comerciales contra el grupo.

El tema principal de la agenda es el debate sobre la posibilidad de impulsar el comercio intra-BRICS utilizando monedas locales en lugar del dólar estadounidense. Trump ha amenazado con imponer aranceles del 100% en caso de que los emergentes avancen en una dirección que desafíe la hegemonía del dólar en el comercio internacional. El 9 de julio vence la tregua concedida por el gobierno estadounidense antes de aplicar nuevos aranceles globales.

Los conflictos internacionales ocupan un lugar prioritario en la agenda. Con la reciente incorporación de Irán al bloque en 2024, los bombardeos realizados en junio por Israel y Estados Unidos intensifican la atención sobre el conflicto en Medio Oriente. Irán pretende que la declaración final de la cumbre condene explícitamente a Israel y Estados Unidos. El conflicto en Ucrania también será objeto de debate. Putin, imposibilitado de viajar a Brasil por la orden de arresto emitida por la Corte Penal Internacional (CPI) por supuestos crímenes de guerra, participará a través de videoconferencia. Trump intenta mediar un alto el fuego con Putin, sin resultados hasta el momento.

La cumbre enfrenta desafíos internos debido a la diversidad del grupo, cuyo peso demográfico representa el 49% de la población mundial. Destacan las dificultades para alcanzar consensos, como ocurrió en la reunión de cancilleres de abril pasado, cuando no se logró firmar una declaración conjunta por desacuerdos sobre la ampliación del Consejo de Seguridad de la Organización de las Naciones Unidas (ONU). Desde 2023, el grupo añadió seis nuevos integrantes: Arabia Saudita, Egipto, Emiratos Árabes Unidos, Etiopía, Indonesia e Irán.

La ausencia de Xi Jinping refuerza las percepciones de distanciamiento de China. Estas ausencias alimentan la percepción de asimetría dentro del foro, ya que China y Rusia son los miembros con mayor peso, y su falta debilita la cohesión interna del bloque.

Bielorrusia participará por primera vez como Estado asociado, representada por su ministro de Exteriores, Maxim Rizhenkov. Bielorrusia obtuvo su estatus de asociado en noviembre de 2024, tras la cumbre en Kazán, Rusia. Otros Estados invitados incluyen a Turquía, Kazajistán, Argelia, Cuba y Bolivia.

La cumbre de los BRICS continuará hasta el lunes.

title: Donald Trump anunciará nuevos aranceles del 70% a las importaciones: ¿Cómo impacta a Argentina?
content: Donald Trump impondrá nuevos aranceles a las importaciones desde agosto. Argentina podría verse afectada, mientras busca un acuerdo comercial con EE. UU.
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, anunciará nuevos aranceles, que regirán desde agosto.
Trump firmó 12 cartas que serán enviadas este lunes 7 de julio a varios países con los que no llegó a acuerdos sobre nuevas tarifas aduaneras.
Los nuevos aranceles oscilarán entre el 60% y el 70%, según el país y el tipo de producto, mientras que algunos países podrían enfrentar una tasa más baja, entre el 10% y el 20%.
La decisión de Trump forma parte de una estrategia para reajustar las políticas comerciales de Estados Unidos.
Las nuevas tarifas generarán ingresos para el país a partir del próximo mes.
Los productos afectados pagarán tasas significativamente más altas al ingresar al mercado estadounidense.
Argentina es uno de los países que se mantiene bajo la observación de los Estados Unidos, ya que desde abril, el país sudamericano ha sido objeto de aranceles adicionales del 10% a sus exportaciones, un porcentaje que se suma a la tasa del 25% impuesta a las importaciones de acero y aluminio.
El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, visitó Buenos Aires en abril para mantener reuniones con el presidente Javier Milei y su equipo económico.
El presidente Milei reafirmó el compromiso de Argentina para ser un aliado estratégico de los Estados Unidos en América Latina.
El anuncio de Trump se produce después de una tregua comercial de 90 días con un mínimo del 10% en vigor hasta el 9 de julio.

title: Trump anuncia este lunes nuevos aranceles de hasta 70%
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos notificará por carta a los países con los que no llegó a acuerdos sobre las nuevas tasas . Qué pasa con Argentina ...
resumen:
Donald Trump anunció nuevos aranceles comerciales de hasta 70%.

El 5 de julio de 2025, Donald Trump anunció que firmó 12 cartas comerciales que serán enviadas el lunes 7 de julio a un grupo de países.

El presidente de Estados Unidos comunicará en ellas los nuevos aranceles establecidos para ingresar determinados productos al territorio estadounidense.

“Me inclino por enviarles una carta indicando qué arancel van a pagar. El valor oscilará entre el 60% o 70% y el 10% o 20%” según el país y el producto, aseguró Trump en conferencia de prensa.

La nueva política tarifaria comenzará a regir el 1 de agosto.

El 2 de abril, Trump impuso “aranceles recíprocos” de entre el 10 y 50% a la mayoría de sus los socios comerciales.

Una semana después decidió pausar la aplicación de la medida y mantuvo un mínimo del 10% de base hasta el 9 de julio.

En mayo, Estados Unidos autorizó una pausa de 90 días para aplicar las nuevas políticas, pero mantuvo un arancel mínimo del 10% hasta el 9 de julio.

Trump logró entendimientos con Reino Unido, Vietnam y China, en los que se pactaron reducciones temporales de los impuestos más elevados.

El lunes 7 de julio, Donald Trump comunicará a cada país el porcentaje que tendrán que pagar desde agosto sus productos para entrar al territorio norteamericano.

Se trata de 12 documentos y resta conocer si la Argentina será uno de los países notificados.

Estados Unidos mantiene para la Argentina aranceles del 10% a las importaciones que suman al recargo del 25% que impuso al acero y al aluminio.

El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent visitó Buenos Aires y se reunió con el presidente Javier Milei y su equipo económico liderado por Luis Caputo.

Milei afirmó: “La Argentina tiene la intención de ser un aliado firme de los Estados Unidos en la región y, de hecho, ha sido el primero de todos en manifestar este compromiso y sostenerlo confiablemente en todas las instancias diplomáticas. Estamos listos para firmar un acuerdo comercial”.

Bessent sostuvo: “Bajo el liderazgo del presidente Milei, la Argentina y Estados Unidos comparten valores similares. Por ese motivo me entusiasmaba hacer este viaje, para dar inicio a las primeras conversaciones formales sobre comercio recíproco entre nuestros dos países”.

title: Trump’s New Vietnam Trade Deal Sizes Up China’s ‘Backdoor’ Tariff Evasion
content: The Trump administration’s new trade deal with Vietnam aims to shut down any “backdoor” routes that allow Chinese goods to ...
resumen: The Trump administration’s new trade deal with Vietnam aims to shut down any “backdoor” routes that allow Chinese goods to circumvent tariffs and flood the U.S. market. The deal, announced on Wednesday by President Donald Trump, imposes a 40% tariff on goods “transshipped” through Vietnam. Trade experts say the provision is aimed at limiting Beijing’s ability to use Southeast Asian nations as a way to bypass U.S. trade restrictions. China has been accused of rerouting shipments to third countries, like Vietnam, in order to evade tariffs imposed on Chinese goods. The practice has reportedly intensified following the Trump administration’s steep “Liberation Day” tariffs, as evidenced by the recent growth of Chinese exports to these countries, according to the Brookings Institution. Frederic Neumann, chief Asia economist for HSBC, told The Wall Street Journal that there appears to be a more strategic intent here by the U.S. to essentially restrict Chinese exports entering the U.S. market via the backdoor. The Trump administration finalized its trade deal with China last week, which resulted in lower tariffs and eased Chinese export controls on critical rare earth elements. The latest deal with Vietnam demonstrates that China remains a central focus of U.S. trade policy and signals to other nations that they must limit Chinese influence in their supply chains to maintain access to the U.S. market, according to the WSJ. Capital Economics economists Mark Williams and Gareth Leather said in a report Thursday, the WSJ reported that these provisions send a clear message to global firms: the recent fall in tariffs between the U.S. and China doesn’t weaken the argument for building supply chains outside China. Similar supply chain measures targeting China were included in the U.S.-U.K. trade pact finalized in May. China’s foreign ministry said in response to that deal that cooperation between states should not be conducted against or to the detriment of the interests of third parties. In addition to the 40% tariff on transshipped goods, Trump announced that the trade deal also imposes a 20% tariff on all goods imported from Vietnam. In exchange, Vietnam agreed to give the U.S. “total access to their markets” by eliminating tariffs on U.S. goods altogether, according to the president. The administration has set a July 9 deadline for countries to finalize trade agreements with the U.S. Countries that fail to reach an agreement by then will face new tariff schedules and “letters” outlining U.S. trade demands, Trump has said.

title: El banco de los BRICS impulsará las divisas locales sin aventurarse a una moneda propia
content: Colombia y Uzbekistán elevan a 11 los países del Sur Global que forman la entidad alternativa al Banco Mundial ...
resumen: El Nuevo Banco de Desarrollo (NBD), conocido como el banco de los BRICS, anunció en su reunión anual en Río de Janeiro (Brasil) que una de sus prioridades estratégicas es “aumentar la financiación y la captación de recursos en monedas locales para reducir la exposición a la volatilidad de los tipos de interés” y de las tasas de cambio, según Dilma Rouseff, presidenta del banco. Rusia es el principal impulsor de la desdolarización, pero encuentra resistencias. El NBD elude emprender una moneda propia. El presidente brasileño, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, se mostró a favor de intensificar el debate sobre una divisa de los BRICS. Fuentes diplomáticas brasileñas explican que las dificultades técnicas, incluso para las transacciones en monedas locales, son enormes y que la vía de los sistemas de pago electrónicos es más prometedora. El debate sobre una moneda de los BRICS y una desdolarización llevaron a Donald Trump a amenazar a los socios del bloque con imponerles aranceles del 100% si seguían en su empeño. El banco de los BRICS, fundado hace una década y con sede en Shangai (China), tiene 122 proyectos, que suponen unos 40.000 millones de dólares, de los que se han desembolsado unos 22.000 millones. Colombia y Uzbekistán se han adherido al nuevo banco de desarrollo, sumándose a Brasil, Rusia, India, China, Sudáfrica, Bangladés, Egipto, Emiratos Unidos y Argelia. Otra de las prioridades de la entidad es avanzar en “la expansión a través de la entrada de nuevos miembros”, según Rouseff. Dentro del banco de los BRICS, “las relaciones están basadas en la igualdad, ningún país domina y todas las voces son oídas. Nadie tiene tampoco poder de veto”.

title: WTO Flags Record Tariff Surge as Global Trade Tensions Escalate in 2025
content: These efforts reflect what the WTO calls “encouraging signs of dialogue,” signaling that nations remain open to negotiated, rules-based solutions, even as trade frictions escalate.
resumen: According to the World Trade Organization (WTO)'s latest Trade Monitoring Update, released on 3 July 2025, a stark surge in global trade-restrictive measures, particularly import tariffs, has pushed the world trading system into its most volatile state since the 2009 global financial crisis. The update covers the period from mid-October 2024 to mid-May 2025. US$ 2.73 trillion worth of global merchandise trade was affected by newly implemented trade-restrictive measures during the review period—more than triple the US$ 887.6 billion reported in the previous 12-month monitoring cycle. This dramatic increase represents the highest level of trade coverage recorded since the WTO began monitoring trade policies in 2009. 19.4% of global merchandise imports are now hit by restrictive measures, a sharp jump from 12.5% at the end of 2024. WTO Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala commented on the report’s findings. The report notes intensified engagement between major trading nations despite the volatile backdrop. Key developments include: The US-China tariff de-escalation agreement signed in Geneva on 14 May 2025, which rolled back select mutual tariff hikes; a follow-up dialogue in London on 11 June, and a US-UK trade agreement finalized in early May, with implementation details shared by mid-June. During the seven-month review period, WTO members and observers implemented a total of 644 trade-related measures, broken down as follows: 296 trade remedy actions, such as anti-dumping and countervailing duties—accounting for 46% of all measures, but covering just US$ 63.9 billion, or 0.26% of world merchandise trade; 141 other restrictive measures, including new tariffs and export bans; 207 trade-facilitating measures, such as tariff eliminations and relaxed import/export quotas. Trade-facilitating measures dropped in both volume and value. Their estimated trade coverage was US$ 1.04 trillion, down from US$ 1.44 trillion in the previous report. The WTO report attributes the dramatic increase in trade restrictions to several converging factors: Rising geopolitical tensions and regional conflicts; domestic protectionist agendas; a shift in policy focus from purely economic stimulus to broader goals, such as climate change mitigation, national and energy security, and supply chain resilience. The report highlights 69 new services trade measures adopted by 34 WTO members and four observers. The report concludes by stressing the need for deep institutional reform of the WTO to meet current global challenges and restore trust in the rules-based multilateral system.

title: Trump says ‘probably 12’ tariff letters being sent out tomorrow
content: US President Donald Trump said Friday that he had signed 12 trade letters to be sent out next week ahead of an impending deadline for his tariffs to take effect.
resumen:
US President Donald Trump said Friday that he had signed 12 trade letters to be sent out next week ahead of an impending deadline for his tariffs to take effect.

Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One, "I signed some letters and they'll go out on Monday, probably 12," adding that the countries that the letters would be sent to will be announced on the same day.

Steeper duties -- which the president said Thursday would range between 10 and 70 percent -- are set to take effect on dozens of economies, from Taiwan to the European Union.

In April, Trump imposed a 10 percent duty on goods from almost all trading partners, with a plan to step up these rates for a select group within days.

He swiftly paused the hikes until July 9, allowing for trade talks to take place.

The Trump administration has unveiled deals with the United Kingdom and Vietnam, while Washington and Beijing agreed to temporarily lower staggeringly high levies on each other's products.

Trump has repeatedly said he plans to inform countries of US tariff rates by sending them letters.

Trump said sending notices would be much easier than "sitting down and working 15 different things."

He said, "You know, with the UK, we did that. And it was great for both parties. With China, we did that, and I think it's very good for both parties."

He said it was "much easier to send a letter saying, 'Listen, we know we have a certain deficit, or in some cases a surplus, but not too many. And... this is what you have to pay, if you want to do business (with) the United States.'".

Crews searched through the dark early Saturday for two dozen children from a girls’ camp and many others who were still missing after a wall of water rushed down a river in the Texas Hill Country during a powerful storm that killed at least 24 people. The death toll was certain to rise. More heavy rains were expected Saturday and flash flood warnings and watches remained in effect for parts of central Texas.

President Donald Trump signed the sprawling megabill designed to jumpstart his domestic policy agenda into law in a July Fourth ceremony at the White House yesterday.

Trump said: “America’s winning, winning, winning like never before,” the president said, also referencing the recent strikes against Iran. “Promises made, promises kept, and we’ve kept them.”

The super-sized domestic policy legislation includes a sharp cliff for tax cuts and deep safety-net restrictions — teeing them up to be the subject of fierce political battles in the 2026 midterms and the 2028 presidential election. The most politically explosive cuts to Medicaid and the nation’s largest food program, for instance, are set to take effect in 2028. Meanwhile, Trump’s most popular tax cuts and a key deduction prized by blue-state Republicans are set to sunset in 2028 and 2029, respectively.

Maine Sen. Susan Collins and Pennsylvania Rep. Brian Fitzpatrick are the only two Republicans who voted against the bill that are currently top targets for Democrats in 2026. The structure of the legislation “ensures that the most politically perilous provisions in the bill will remain a hot potato — and an opportunity for moderates — for years to come.”

The benefit cuts could crop up in the 2028 presidential race, too, when VP JD Vance, who cast the tie-breaking vote in the Senate and is seen as a key salesman for it, will likely be vying for the presidency. Lawmakers in virtually every state will face pressure in 2028 as provisions kick in requiring most states to shoulder part of the costs of federal food aid for the first time.

The new law delivers the White House $170 billion for border and immigration enforcement. The Trump administration has three-and-a-half years to drastically expand the nation’s border enforcement and deportation infrastructure.

The general consensus from blue state governors and lawmakers boils down to: Sit tight for now and blame Republicans. Congress’ Medicaid cuts came as dozens of state legislatures dried the ink on their own annual budgets and adjourned — some for the summer, many for the year.

State governments are already “bracing for impact as Washington shifts much of the burden for health care, food assistance and other programs onto them.”

Passing the megabill was the hard part. Now comes the other hard part: Selling it to an American public. Voters are still deeply unfamiliar with everything that’s in the new law and how it will impact communities across the country. Polls show that the bill is unpopular. Opposition outweighed support by more than 20 percentage points in recent Fox News and Quinnipiac University polls. Some Republican lawmakers facing tough races next year represent the most Medicaid-reliant districts. They will have to defend the big cuts in the bill to Medicaid, the health-insurance program for low-income and disabled people, as well as to rural hospitals and to nutrition assistance, once known as food stamps. Those cuts help fund tax cuts in the bill that President Trump called for during the 2024 campaign.

Gross domestic product shrank in the first quarter of the year in part because of surging imports, and consumers are feeling hesitant and spending less. It’s also too soon to know the full effect of Trump’s widespread tariffs, especially with a deadline approaching to get deals completed with many countries before levies rise once more. As immigrants leave the workforce, either voluntarily or by deportation, a lack of workers could create labor shortages in certain key areas and fuel wage inflation.

They haven’t briefed me on it,” Trump said last night when asked about Hamas’ positive reaction. “There could be a Gaza deal next week,” he added, saying he’s optimistic but “it changes from day to day.” Israel PM Benjamin Netanyahu is set to visit the White House on Monday.

title: What traders have gotten wrong in 2025
content: World conflicts and President Trump's turbulent policy making have shattered assumptions, leaving market favorites in tatters and conjuring unexpected winners.
resumen:
Six months since Wall Street laid out its predictions for 2025, world conflicts and President Donald Trump’s turbulent policymaking have shattered assumptions about the strength and preeminence of U.S. assets and the economy, leaving market favorites in tatters and conjuring unexpected winners.

Swings in sovereign bond markets have been sharp, the Japanese yen rallied, and a comeback for emerging markets is finally materializing.

Few envisaged the dollar would suffer losses this deep, or predicted the S&P 500’s giddying plunge followed by breakneck rebound.

Europe’s stock market has morphed from backwater into investor must-have.

Simon Dangoor, head of fixed-income macro strategies at Goldman Sachs Asset Management, said a “very significant evolution” has occurred in markets in the past six months.

A Bloomberg gauge of the U.S. currency posted its worst start to a year since at least 2005, and its hegemony is being debated ever more fiercely.

The “Liberation Day” tariffs at the start of April fueled fears of a U.S. recession and fanned speculation Trump was seeking to buoy domestic manufacturing by engineering a weaker dollar.

Societe Generale, Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase & Co. hadn’t expected a turn in the dollar’s fortunes in the first half and only predicted gradual slippage later in the year.

A JPMorgan team led by Meera Chandan says the greenback’s faltering link to rates and equities could be a sign of structural weaknesses. They predict a gauge of the U.S. currency’s strength will drop another 2% by year-end.

Investors entered the year with a record high allocation to U.S. stocks, emboldened by a robust economy and bets around artificial intelligence.

Nearly $7 trillion of market capitalization was wiped from the technology-heavy Nasdaq 100 Index between a February peak and an April low.

A Bank of America fund manager survey showed the biggest-ever drop in exposure to U.S. stocks in March.

Trump’s decision later that month to pause some of the highest tariffs in a century proved pivotal.

The S&P 500 hit a record high as data shows the economy chugging along and with technology heavyweights in vogue again.

Traders started 2025 confident they’d see a rally in the yen.

JPMorgan Asset Management and Brandywine Global Investment Management were among those proved right by the currency’s almost 9% surge against the dollar to around 145 this year.

Jupiter Asset Management’s Mark Nash forecasts the currency will climb to 120 per dollar by year-end, an advance of around 17% from current levels.

In China, U.S. trade tariffs were expected to hurt the yuan, but so far the dollar’s own sharp sell-off has upended the prediction.

Short-dated government bonds were expected to perform well, boosted by central bank interest-rate cuts as inflation eased further.

Long-dated bonds were predicted to come under pressure as governments took on increasing levels of debt to plug deepening fiscal deficits and ramped up public spending.

As of June 27, the benchmark Stoxx 600 index had trounced the S&P 500 by 16 percentage points in dollar terms, the best relative performance since 2006.

The euro has surged to $1.17, bucking widespread forecasts for parity with the dollar in early 2025.

Every year since 2017, emerging-market equities lagged U.S. stocks.

In 2025, a procession of money managers — with Morgan Stanley among the most vocal — were convinced it was going to be different.

A boom in AI companies from Taiwan, South Korea and China have helped the equity index.

The overall investment case for emerging markets is underpinned by broad currency strength against the greenback and the perception that the period of U.S. exceptionalism is waning.

Alice Gledhill, Malavika Kaur Makol and Sagarika Jaisinghani Bloomberg wrote the article.

Bloomberg’s Carter Johnson, Selcuk Gokoluk, Andras Gergely, Alice Atkins, Naomi Tajitsu, Michael Msika, Srinivasan Sivabalan and Kevin Simauchi contributed.

resumen: En Río de Janeiro, fuerzas especiales del Ejército y la Armada brasileña vigilan la ciudad. Un grupo especializado en ataques químicos, biológicos, radiológicos y nucleares tomó posiciones en el Museo de Arte Moderno, en el Parque Flamengo, cerca del Aeropuerto Santos Dumont. Este domingo y lunes, en ese sitio se reúnen los líderes de las naciones en donde vive la mitad de la población del planeta y se generan cuatro de cada diez dólares de la economía mundial. La décimo séptima cumbre de jefes de Estado y de gobierno del BRICS, un grupo formado en 2009 por Brasil, Rusia, India y China, al que luego se unió Sudáfrica tiene lugar este año después de la ampliación aprobada en octubre pasado, en Kazán, Rusia. Ahora son 11 miembros de pleno más otros 10 países asociados, entre ellos los latinoamericanos Cuba y Bolivia. Vistas en conjunto, esas naciones producen 43 de cada 100 barriles del petróleo del mundo y realizan una cuarta parte del comercio global. El presidente Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva describió el escenario global actual como cada vez más inestable, marcado por el resurgimiento del proteccionismo, el unilateralismo y el impacto de la crisis climática. Su crítica al unilateralismo alcanzó a la Organización de Naciones Unidas (ONU). Lula, en un foro auspiciado por el Nuevo Banco de Desarrollo (NDB, por sus siglas en inglés), conocido como el banco de los BRICS, también lo dejó ver Dilma Rousseff, ex presidenta brasileña y actual directora del NDB, que tiene su sede en Shanghái, China. Además de los cinco países cuyos iniciales dan nombre al BRICS, pertenecen al grupo Arabia Saudita, Egipto, Emiratos Árabes Unidos, Etiopía, Indonesia e Irán. Además, con carácter de asociados, se incorporan a esta cumbre Bielorrusia, Bolivia, Cuba, Kazajistán, Malasia, Nigeria, Tailandia, Uganda, Uzbekistán y Vietnam. En enero pasado, el presidente Lula invitó a la presidenta mexicana Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo a unirse a la cumbre de este año, pero la mandataria declinó la invitación. En las reuniones de este domingo y lunes estará representada por el canciller Juan Ramón de la Fuente. Lula defendió la creación de un nuevo modelo de financiamiento para los países en desarrollo sostenible y sin condicionamientos. También defendió el uso de monedas locales en las operaciones entre los países de este mecanismo, hace dos meses, Trump amagó con imponer un arancel del 100 por ciento a los países que dejaran el dólar. Este viernes, los ministros de Finanzas del bloque pusieron a punto una propuesta para ser incluida en las discusiones de los jefes de Estado el próximo domingo, con el fin de avanzar en un impuesto a las grandes fortunas, tema que la semana pasada sufrió un revés cuando el Grupo de los 7 países más avanzados decidió excluir a las trasnacionales estadunidenses de un gravamen de ese tipo, por presión del presidente Trump.

title: PM to attend BRICS Summit at Rio de Janeiro tomorrow, to be followed by State visit to Brasilia
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi will be in Brazil tomorrow to attend the 17th BRICS Summit at Rio de Janeiro (July 6-7), and then travel to Brasilia on a bilateral State visit and hold discussions ...
resumen: Prime Minister Narendra Modi will be in Brazil tomorrow to attend the 17th BRICS Summit at Rio de Janeiro (July 6-7), and then travel to Brasilia on a bilateral State visit and hold discussions with Brazilian President Lula da Silva. Both countries are expected to sign several agreements and Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs). PM Modi's state visit to Brasilia will break an almost six decade hiatus at the Prime Ministerial level. The visit aims at strengthening bilateral ties, with discussions expected to focus on trade and strategic collaboration. India’s Ambassador to Brazil, Dinesh Bhatia, said the visit will build on long-standing ties between India and Brazil which date back to the establishment of India's first embassy in Latin America in 1948. At the BRICS Summit, Prime Minister Modi will engage with global leaders on wide-ranging topics such as global health, artificial intelligence and climate finance. Post the Rio Summit, the Prime Minister will hold discussions with Brazilian President Lula da Silva in Brasilia, with both sides expected to sign several Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs). The External Affairs Ministry said PM Modi’s bilateral talks in Brazil will cover trade expansion, defence cooperation, energy collaboration, technological innovation, and people-to-people ties. The BRICS Summit will have two Plenary Sessions tomorrow on the opening day on ‘Strengthening Multi-lateralism, Economic-Financial Affairs and Artificial Intelligence’ and ‘Peace and Security and Reform of Global Governance.’ On July 7 it will have a Plenary Session ‘Environment, COP30 and Global Health.’ The Theme of the Summit is 'Strengthening Global South Cooperation for more Inclusive and Sustainable Governance'. Discussions will focus primarily on how BRICS presents alternative avenues to reshape South-South cooperation on trade and investment and financing. Discussions will also include topics like reform of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and transition towards green energy. With the addition of Vietnam, the extended BRICS now has 20 members out of which ten are Partner Countries. The ten BRICS members are Brazil, Russia, India, China, South Africa, Egypt, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Iran and the UAE. The ten Partner Countries are Belarus, Bolivia, Cuba, Kazakhstan, Malaysia, Nigeria, Thailand, Uganda, Uzbekistan and Vietnam. The establishment of the BRICS Partner Country category was approved during the Kazan Summit in Russia in 2024. Together BRICS countries now make up nearly 44 percent of global GDP and 56 per cent of Global population.

title: BRICS Set to Condemn Trade-Distorting Tariffs in Swipe at Trump
content: BRICS leaders are poised to adopt a position at odds with President Donald Trump on trade tariffs, conflict in the Middle East and global arms spending, even as they shy away from any direct challenge ...
resumen:
BRICS leaders are poised to adopt a position at odds with President Donald Trump on trade tariffs, conflict in the Middle East and global arms spending, even as they shy away from any direct challenge to the US.

In a draft statement prepared for their meeting in Brazil starting Sunday, leaders agreed to voice “serious concerns” about the rise of unilateral tariff and non-tariff measures “which distort trade and are inconsistent with WTO rules,” according to a version of the final text.

The government chiefs additionally agreed to “condemn the imposition of unilateral coercive measures that are contrary to international law,” specifically economic sanctions, the text states.

While not mentioning the Trump administration by name, leading emerging-market nations are clearly referring to the US in the wake of the president’s tariffs imposed on countries worldwide.

Facing punitive levies, nations including founding BRICS member India are racing to strike deals with the US ahead of a July 9 deadline Trump has given for the tariffs to take effect.

Members are still unable to identify a common position regarding representation on the UN Security Council.

BRICS nations hosted in Rio de Janeiro by Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva are at cross-purposes with the Trump administration on multiple aspects of policy.

That includes underscoring the role of the World Health Organization as “essential to effectively address current and future public health challenges” — while Trump notified the WHO of the US intention to withdraw in January.

It extends to aspects of policy regarding the Middle East, with leaders agreeing to condemn military strikes against BRICS member Iran since June 13, when Israel began its attacks, culminating in US airstrikes on June 22.

These strikes “constitute a violation of international law and the Charter of the United Nations,” according to the draft BRICS statement, in which leaders “express grave concern over the subsequent escalation of the security situation in the Middle East.”

The BRICS leaders further express “grave concern about the situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territory,” citing the resumption of Israeli attacks and the obstruction of the entry of humanitarian aid into Gaza.

They condemn violations of international human rights law, according to the draft, “including the use of starvation as a method of warfare” — a reference to allegations leveled at Israel of withholding humanitarian aid, charges which it rejects.

They agreed to call for the full withdraw of Israeli forces from the Gaza Strip under a permanent and unconditional ceasefire, as well as the release of all hostages, while expressing their opposition to the forced displacement of any of the Palestinian population from their territory.

BRICS leaders additionally “express alarm” at the current trend of “a critical increase in global military spending,” according to the draft.

BRICS leaders are also set to express their backing for the Paris climate agreement — a pact which Trump unilaterally abandoned — while calling for global governance of artificial intelligence to mitigate potential risks, according to the officials.

The BRICS nations are Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa, as well as more recent full members Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran, Indonesia and the United Arab Emirates.

The declaration welcomes a further 10 nations as partner countries, including Kazakhstan, Nigeria, Vietnam and Thailand.

content: With sweeping tariffs on friend and foe, US President Donald Trump has roiled financial markets and sparked a surge in economic uncertainty -- and tensions are mounting days before a fresh volley of ...
resumen:
US President Donald Trump has implemented sweeping tariffs, roiling financial markets and sparking economic uncertainty. Levies on dozens of economies are set to bounce from 10 percent to a range between 11 percent and 50 percent on Wednesday.

GLOBAL TARIFFS: Trump imposed a 10 percent tariff on most US trading partners in April, with the rate set to rise for dozens of economies including the European Union and Japan. The UK and Vietnam have struck pacts with the United States, while China has managed to temporarily lower tit-for-tat duties. Canada and Mexico are not affected by the 10 percent global tariff. Copper, pharmaceuticals, semiconductors and lumber are also off the hook, as are gold, silver, and energy commodities.

CHINA FOCUS: China has borne the brunt of Trump's levies. Both sides imposed triple-digit tariffs on each other's goods at one point. Washington agreed to lower its levies on Chinese goods to 30 percent and Beijing slashed its own to 10 percent. The US level is higher as it includes a 20 percent tariff imposed over China's alleged role in the global fentanyl trade.

AUTOS, METAL: Trump imposed a 25 percent levy on steel and aluminum imports in March, doubling them to 50 percent last month. He has also rolled out a 25 percent tariff on imported autos, although those imported under the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) can qualify for a lower levy.

CANADA, MEXICO: Canadian and Mexican products were initially hard hit by 25 percent US tariffs, with a lower rate for Canadian energy. Trump targeted both neighbors saying they did not do enough on illegal immigration and the flow of illicit drugs across borders. He eventually announced exemptions for goods entering his country under the USMCA. Potash, used as fertilizer, got a lower rate as well.

OTHER THREATS: Trump ordered the closure of a duty-free exemption for low-value parcels from China. He has opened the door for 25 percent tariffs on goods from countries importing Venezuelan oil and has threatened similar "secondary tariffs" involving Russian oil. He has ordered investigations into imports of copper, lumber, semiconductors, pharmaceuticals and critical minerals that could eventually bring new duties.

LEGAL CHALLENGES: The US Court of International Trade ruled in May that Trump had overstepped his authority with across-the-board global levies. It blocked many of the duties from going into effect, prompting the Trump administration's challenge, and a US federal appeals court has since allowed the duties to remain while it considers the case.

title: China levels major tariffs on European brandy amid tensions with US allies
content: China on Friday imposed anti-dumping duties on European brandy, most notably cognac produced in France, as trade tensions between Beijing and United States allies continue to rise.
resumen:
China imposed anti-dumping duties on European brandy, mainly cognac from France, due to rising trade tensions with US allies.
Chinese authorities agreed to exempt some major cognac makers if they maintain prices above minimum levels.
The tariffs, effective today, will range from 27.7% to 34.9% and will be in place for five years, not applied retroactively.
French President Emmanuel Macron said the exemptions are a positive step towards ending the dispute.
Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi was on a European visit to address trade differences, with stops in Brussels and Berlin before Paris.
French Foreign Minister Jean-Noël Barrot will discuss the issue with Wang.
The anti-dumping duties resulted from a probe China launched last year into European brandy, following an EU probe into Chinese electric vehicle subsidies.
The Commerce Ministry stated that dumping of imported brandy from the EU existed, causing a material threat to the domestic brandy industry.
China has also launched investigations into European pork and dairy products.
China initially announced provisional tariffs of 30.6% to 39% on French cognac producer Remy Martin and other European brandies.
Exemptions include French producers Pernod Ricard, Remy Cointreau, and Hennessy.
Barrot praised the exemptions as a positive step but noted that some issues remain unresolved, particularly the exclusion of certain players.
Wang’s European tour precedes a China-EU summit focused on trade in Beijing later this month.

title: Trade relations hang in the balance as China’s top diplomat tours Europe
content: China’s top diplomat Wang Yi’s high-profile tour of Europe this week has been dominated by deepening trade tensions and mounting security concerns, with relations between Beijing and the European ...
resumen:
China’s top diplomat Wang Yi’s tour of Europe this week has been dominated by deepening trade tensions and mounting security concerns, with relations between Beijing and the European Union their most strained in years.

China’s commerce ministry moved to massively increase some tariffs on EU products. The Chinese ministry announced the measure on Friday, said its investigations had found that EU brandy was being dumped on the Chinese market, threatening domestic producers. The country's anti-dumping duties of up to 34.9 percent on European brandy imports will take effect on 5 July.

A number of predominantly French producers – including leading Cognac houses Pernod Ricard, Rémy Cointreau and Hennessy – have consented to sell their products in China at prices no lower than a predetermined minimum. Starting from 5 July, these firms will be permitted to operate under this pricing scheme as an alternative to paying the duties.

China's measure follows the EU’s imposition of up to 35 percent tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) last October, citing unfair subsidies. Beijing has denied the allegations and responded with probes into European pork, dairy, and now brandy. The dispute has reached the World Trade Organization, which is reviewing the EU’s actions.

China and the EU are set to mark 50 years of diplomatic ties at a summit later this month, although reports suggest Beijing may cancel part of the event amid the tensions.

German Foreign Minister Johann Wadephul criticised China’s "unilateral and often not very transparent" export restrictions on rare earths, which are vital for industries including electric vehicles and electronics. Since April, China has required export licences for these strategic materials, causing global concern as it controls nearly two-thirds of mining and 92 percent of refining. German businesses have voiced alarm over the uncertainty, which Wadephul warned is damaging China’s reputation as a reliable partner.

Wang defended the controls, calling rare earths "dual-use goods" with both civilian and military applications, and insisted that export management is a matter of sovereignty. He proposed a "green channel" to ease exports to the EU, but the issue remains a sticking point as Europe seeks to reduce its dependency on Chinese supply chains.

EU foreign affairs chief Kaja Kallas accused China of undermining European security by supporting Russia’s war effort in Ukraine, conducting cyberattacks, interfering in democratic processes and engaging in unfair trade practices. Kallas said that Chinese companies are Moscow’s lifeline to sustain its war against Ukraine, adding that these actions harm European security and jobs.

Wang rejected the accusations, insisting that China is not supplying lethal weapons to Russia and portraying Beijing as a neutral party seeking peace. He warned against "confrontation" and urged the EU to pursue a more pragmatic relationship, adding that "China is not the United States" and should not be treated as such.

President Trump’s 9 July deadline for new tariffs is looming, and failure to reach a deal could see levies on EU imports double to 20 percent or more. Germany, Europe’s industrial powerhouse, is particularly vulnerable, as the US is a key market for its exports. Recent data showed German industrial orders fell by 1.4 percent in May.

French President Emmanuel Macron has called for an EU-US trade deal "as soon as possible, with the lowest tariffs possible," arguing for open markets rather than protectionism. EU trade chief Maros Sefcovic is in Washington for last-ditch talks, with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen declaring the bloc “ready for a deal".
